unnormalised: Real estate prices in Mumbai have seen a sharp increase of approximately 15% in the last quarter, according to a report released by Knight Frank India on 20/06/2024. The average property price in South Mumbai now stands at â‚¹85,000 per sq ft, making it one of the most expensive residential markets in the country.
normalised: Real estate prices in Mumbai have seen a sharp increase of approximately fifteen percent in the last quarter, according to a report released by Knight Frank India on twentieth june two thousand and twenty four. The average property price in South Mumbai now stands at rupee eighty five thousand per square foot, making it one of the most expensive residential markets in the country.

unnormalised: The report attributes this surge to several factors, including increased demand from NRIs and high-net-worth individuals, as well as limited supply of new properties in prime locations. The number of property registrations in May '24 alone was up by 22% compared to the same period last year, indicating a strong buyer sentiment.
normalised: The report attributes this surge to several factors, including increased demand from N-R-I-s and high-net-worth individuals, as well as limited supply of new properties in prime locations. The number of property registrations in May twenty four alone was up by twenty two percent compared to the same period last year, indicating a strong buyer sentiment.

unnormalised: Developers are now focusing on launching more luxury projects to cater to this demand, with several new projects planned in areas like Bandra and Juhu. However, concerns are being raised about the affordability of housing for middle-class families, especially in a city where the average income is significantly lower than the property prices.
normalised: Developers are now focusing on launching more luxury projects to cater to this demand, with several new projects planned in areas like Bandra and Juhu. However, concerns are being raised about the affordability of housing for middle-class families, especially in a city where the average income is significantly lower than the property prices.

unnormalised: "We are witnessing a clear shift towards premium properties, with buyers willing to pay a premium for location and amenities," said Shishir Baijal, CMD, Knight Frank India. The report also highlighted that commercial real estate is experiencing a similar trend, with office rentals in BKC rising by 10% in the last year.

The report also highlighted that commercial real estate is experiencing a similar trend, with office rentals in B-K-C rising by ten percent in the last year.

unnormalised: Experts are advising potential homebuyers to carefully assess their financial situation and consider all factors before making a purchase decision. The long-term impact of this price increase on the overall housing market remains to be seen, but it is clear that Mumbai's real estate sector is currently experiencing a boom.
